scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-235 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-235 is a star with 0.58 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.55 times its radius. It is located 1396.01 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 6 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-235 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-235 system


Kepler-235 b

Kepler-235 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-235 b is 5.597 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-235 b is 2.230 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-235 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


Kepler-235 c

Kepler-235 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-235 c is 2.185 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-235 c is 1.280 that of Earth. At 2.185 Earth masses, Kepler-235 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Kepler-235 d

Kepler-235 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-235 d is 4.865 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-235 d is 2.050 that of Earth. With a mass below 5 Earth masses, a density of 3.1, and a semi-major axis of 0.122 astronomical units, Kepler-235 d could, potentially, be an ocean world - a planet with no dry land.


Kepler-235 e

Kepler-235 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.21 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-235 e is 5.565 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-235 e is 2.220 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-235 e is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-235, which contains 4 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-235 - System With 4 Exoplanets
